docs.name: s

params.description: The sound / pattern of sounds to pick
params.name: sound

docs.comment:
/**
   * The note or sample number to choose for a synth or sampleset
   * Note names currently not working yet, but will hopefully soon. Just stick to numbers for now
   *
   * @name n
   * @param {string | number | Pattern} value note name, note number or sample number
   * @example
   * s('superpiano').n("<0 1 2 3>").osc()
   * @example
   * s('superpiano').n("<c4 d4 e4 g4>").osc()
   * @example
   * n("0 1 2 3").s('east').osc()
   */
docs.description: The note or sample number to choose for a synth or sampleset Note names currently not working yet, but will hopefully soon. Just stick to numbers for now
docs.name: n

params.description: note name, note number or sample number
params.name: value

docs.comment:
/**
   * A pattern of numbers that speed up (or slow down) samples while they play. Currently only supported by osc / superdirt.
   *
   * @name accelerate
   * @param {number | Pattern} amount acceleration.
   * @example
   * s("sax").accelerate("<0 1 2 4 8 16>").slow(2).osc()
   *
   */
docs.description: A pattern of numbers that speed up (or slow down) samples while they play. Currently only supported by osc / superdirt.
docs.name: accelerate

docs.comment:
/**
   * Like {@link amp}, but exponential.
   *
   * @name gain
   * @param {number | Pattern} amount gain.
   * @example
   * s("bd*8").gain(".7*2 1 .7*2 1 .7 1").osc()
   *
   */
docs.description: Like {@link amp}, but exponential.
docs.name: gain

docs.comment:
/**
   * Like {@link gain}, but linear.
   *
   * @name amp
   * @param {number | Pattern} amount gain.
   * @example
   * s("bd*8").amp(".1*2 .5 .1*2 .5 .1 .5").osc()
   *
   */
docs.description: Like {@link gain}, but linear.
docs.name: amp

docs.comment:
/**
   * Sets the center frequency of the band-pass filter.
   *
   * @name bandf
   * @param {number | Pattern} frequency center frequency
   * @example
   * s("bd sd").bandf("<1000 2000 4000 8000>").osc()
   *
   */
docs.description: Sets the center frequency of the band-pass filter.
docs.name: bandf

docs.comment:
/**
   * Sets the q-factor of the band-pass filter
   *
   * @name bandq
   * @param {number | Pattern} q q factor
   * @example
   * s("bd sd").bandf(2000).bandq("<.2 .9>").osc()
   *
   */
docs.description: Sets the q-factor of the band-pass filter
docs.name: bandq

docs.comment:
/**
   * a pattern of numbers from 0 to 1. Skips the beginning of each sample, e.g. `0.25` to cut off the first quarter from each sample.
   *
   * @name begin
   * @param {number | Pattern} amount between 0 and 1, where 1 is the length of the sample
   * @example
   * s("rave").begin("<0 .25 .5 .75>").osc()
   *
   */
docs.description: a pattern of numbers from 0 to 1. Skips the beginning of each sample, e.g. 0.25 to cut off the first quarter from each sample.
docs.name: begin

params.description: between 0 and 1, where 1 is the length of the sample
params.name: amount

docs.comment:
/**
   * The same as {@link begin}, but cuts off the end off each sample.
   *
   * @name end
   * @param {number | Pattern} length 1 = whole sample, .5 = half sample, .25 = quarter sample etc..
   * @example
   * s("bd*2,ho*4").end("<.1 .2 .5 1>").osc()
   *
   */
docs.description: The same as {@link begin}, but cuts off the end off each sample.
docs.name: end

params.description: 1 = whole sample, .5 = half sample, .25 = quarter sample etc..
params.name: length

docs.comment:
/**
   * Loops the sample (from `begin` to `end`) the specified number of times.
   * Note that the tempo of the loop is not synced with the cycle tempo.
   *
   * @name loop
   * @param {number | Pattern} times How often the sample is looped
   * @example
   * s("bd").loop("<1 2 3 4>").osc()
   *
   */
docs.description: Loops the sample (from begin to end) the specified number of times. Note that the tempo of the loop is not synced with the cycle tempo.
docs.name: loop

docs.comment:
/**
   * a pattern of numbers from 0 to 1. Skips the beginning of each sample, e.g. `0.25` to cut off the first quarter from each sample.
   *
   * @name legato
   * @param {number | Pattern} duration between 0 and 1, where 1 is the length of the whole hap time
   * @example
   * "c4 eb4 g4 bb4".legato("<0.125 .25 .5 .75 1 2 4>")
   *
   */
docs.description: a pattern of numbers from 0 to 1. Skips the beginning of each sample, e.g. 0.25 to cut off the first quarter from each sample.
docs.name: legato

params.description: between 0 and 1, where 1 is the length of the whole hap time
params.name: duration

docs.comment:
/**
   * bit crusher effect.
   *
   * @name crush
   * @param {number | Pattern} depth between 1 (for drastic reduction in bit-depth) to 16 (for barely no reduction).
   * @example
   * s("<bd sd>,hh*3,jvbass*2").fast(2).crush("<16 8 7 6 5 4 3 2>").osc()
   *
   */
docs.description: bit crusher effect.
docs.name: crush

params.description: between 1 (for drastic reduction in bit-depth) to 16 (for barely no reduction).
params.name: depth

docs.comment:
/**
   * fake-resampling for lowering the sample rate
   *
   * @name coarse
   * @param {number | Pattern} factor 1 for original 2 for half, 3 for a third and so on.
   * @example
   * s("xmas").coarse("<1 4 8 16 32>").osc()
   *
   */
docs.description: fake-resampling for lowering the sample rate
docs.name: coarse

params.description: 1 for original 2 for half, 3 for a third and so on.
params.name: factor

docs.comment:
/**
   * choose the channel the pattern is sent to in superdirt
   *
   * @name channel
   * @param {number | Pattern} channel channel number
   *
   */
docs.description: choose the channel the pattern is sent to in superdirt
docs.name: channel

docs.comment:
/**
   * In the style of classic drum-machines, `cut` will stop a playing sample as soon as another samples with in same cutgroup is to be played. An example would be an open hi-hat followed by a closed one, essentially muting the open.
   *
   * @name cut
   * @param {number | Pattern} group cut group number
   * @example
   * s("bd sax").cut(1).osc()
   *
   */
docs.description: In the style of classic drum-machines, cut will stop a playing sample as soon as another samples with in same cutgroup is to be played. An example would be an open hi-hat followed by a closed one, essentially muting the open.
docs.name: cut

docs.comment:
/**
   * Applies the cutoff frequency of the low-pass filter.
   *
   * @name cutoff
   * @param {number | Pattern} frequency audible between 0 and 20000
   * @example
   * s("bd,hh*2,<~ sd>").fast(2).cutoff("<4000 2000 1000 500 200 100>").osc()
   *
   */
docs.description: Applies the cutoff frequency of the low-pass filter.
docs.name: cutoff

docs.comment:
/**
   * Applies the cutoff frequency of the high-pass filter.
   *
   * @name hcutoff
   * @param {number | Pattern} frequency audible between 0 and 20000
   * @example
   * s("bd,hh*2,<~ sd>").fast(2).hcutoff("<4000 2000 1000 500 200 100>").osc()
   *
   */
docs.description: Applies the cutoff frequency of the high-pass filter.
docs.name: hcutoff

docs.comment:
/**
   * Applies the cutoff frequency of the high-pass filter.
   *
   * @name hresonance
   * @param {number | Pattern} q resonance factor between 0 and 1
   * @example
   * s("bd,hh*2,<~ sd>").fast(2).hcutoff(2000).hresonance("<0 .2 .4 .6>").osc()
   *
   */
docs.description: Applies the cutoff frequency of the high-pass filter.
docs.name: hresonance

docs.comment:
/**
   * Applies the cutoff frequency of the low-pass filter.
   *
   * @name resonance
   * @param {number | Pattern} q resonance factor between 0 and 1
   * @example
   * s("bd,hh*2,<~ sd>").fast(2).cutoff(2000).resonance("<0 .2 .4 .6>").osc()
   *
   */
docs.description: Applies the cutoff frequency of the low-pass filter.
docs.name: resonance

docs.comment: /** * Set detune of oscillators. Works only with some synths, see tidal doc * * @name djf * @param {number | Pattern} cutoff below 0.5 is low pass filter, above is high pass filter * @example * n("0 3 7 [10,24]").s('superzow').octave(3).djf("<.5 .25 .5 .75>").osc() * */
docs.description: Set detune of oscillators. Works only with some synths, see tidal doc
docs.name: djf

params.description: below 0.5 is low pass filter, above is high pass filter
params.name: cutoff

docs.comment: /** * Set detune of oscillators. Works only with some synths, see tidal doc * * @name detune * @param {number | Pattern} amount between 0 and 1 * @example * n("0 3 7").s('superzow').octave(3).detune("<0 .25 .5 1 2>").osc() * */
docs.description: Set detune of oscillators. Works only with some synths, see tidal doc
docs.name: detune

docs.comment:
/**
   * Set dryness of reverb. See {@link room} and {@link size} for more information about reverb.
   *
   * @name dry
   * @param {number | Pattern} dry 0 = wet, 1 = dry
   * @example
   * n("[0,3,7](3,8)").s("superpiano").room(.7).dry("<0 .5 .75 1>").osc()
   *
   */
docs.description: Set dryness of reverb. See {@link room} and {@link size} for more information about reverb.
docs.name: dry

docs.comment:
/**
   * Set frequency of sound.
   *
   * @name freq
   * @param {number | Pattern} frequency in Hz. the audible range is between 20 and 20000 Hz
   * @example
   * freq("220 110 440 110").s("superzow").osc()
   * @example
   * freq("110".mulOut(".5 1.5 .6 [2 3]")).s("superzow").osc()
   *
   */
docs.description: Set frequency of sound.
docs.name: freq

params.description: in Hz. the audible range is between 20 and 20000 Hz
params.name: frequency

docs.comment:
/**
   * Emulation of a Leslie speaker: speakers rotating in a wooden amplified cabinet.
   *
   * @name leslie
   * @param {number | Pattern} wet between 0 and 1
   * @example
   * n("0,4,7").s("supersquare").leslie("<0 .4 .6 1>").osc()
   *
   */
docs.description: Emulation of a Leslie speaker: speakers rotating in a wooden amplified cabinet.
docs.name: leslie

docs.comment:
/**
   * Rate of modulation / rotation for leslie effect
   *
   * @name lrate
   * @param {number | Pattern} rate 6.7 for fast, 0.7 for slow
   * @example
   * n("0,4,7").s("supersquare").leslie(1).lrate("<1 2 4 8>").osc()
   *
   */
docs.description: Rate of modulation / rotation for leslie effect
docs.name: lrate

docs.comment:
/**
   * Physical size of the cabinet in meters. Be careful, it might be slightly larger than your computer. Affects the Doppler amount (pitch warble)
   *
   * @name lsize
   * @param {number | Pattern} meters somewhere between 0 and 1
   * @example
   * n("0,4,7").s("supersquare").leslie(1).lrate(2).lsize("<.1 .5 1>").osc()
   *
   */
docs.description: Physical size of the cabinet in meters. Be careful, it might be slightly larger than your computer. Affects the Doppler amount (pitch warble)
docs.name: lsize

docs.comment:
/**
   * Sets the default octave of a synth.
   *
   * @name octave
   * @param {number | Pattern} octave octave number
   * @example
   * n("0,4,7").s('supersquare').octave("<3 4 5 6>").osc()
   */
docs.description: Sets the default octave of a synth.
docs.name: octave

docs.comment:
/**
   * a pattern of numbers. An `orbit` is a global parameter context for patterns. Patterns with the same orbit will share hardware output bus offset and global effects, e.g. reverb and delay. The maximum number of orbits is specified in the superdirt startup, numbers higher than maximum will wrap around.
   *
   * @name orbit
   * @param {number | Pattern} number
   *
   */
docs.description: a pattern of numbers. An orbit is a global parameter context for patterns. Patterns with the same orbit will share hardware output bus offset and global effects, e.g. reverb and delay. The maximum number of orbits is specified in the superdirt startup, numbers higher than maximum will wrap around.
docs.name: orbit

docs.comment:
/**
   * Sets position in stereo.
   *
   * @name pan
   * @param {number | Pattern} pan between 0 and 1, from left to right (assuming stereo), once round a circle (assuming multichannel)
   * @example
   * s("[bd hh]*2").pan("<.5 1 .5 0>").osc()
   *
   */
docs.description: Sets position in stereo.
docs.name: pan

params.description: between 0 and 1, from left to right (assuming stereo), once round a circle (assuming multichannel)
params.name: pan

docs.comment:
/**
   * Sets the level of reverb.
   *
   * @name room
   * @param {number | Pattern} level between 0 and 1
   * @example
   * s("bd sd").room("<0 .2 .4 .6 .8 1>").osc()
   *
   */
docs.description: Sets the level of reverb.
docs.name: room

docs.comment:
/**
   * Sets the room size of the reverb, see {@link room}.
   *
   * @name size
   * @param {number | Pattern} size between 0 and 1
   * @example
   * s("bd sd").room(.8).size("<0 .2 .4 .6 .8 1>").osc()
   *
   */
docs.description: Sets the room size of the reverb, see {@link room}.
docs.name: size

docs.comment:
/**
   * Wave shaping distortion. CAUTION: it might get loud
   *
   * @name shape
   * @param {number | Pattern} distortion between 0 and 1
   * @example
   * s("bd sd").shape("<0 .2 .4 .6 .8 1>").osc()
   *
   */
docs.description: Wave shaping distortion. CAUTION: it might get loud
docs.name: shape

docs.comment:
/**
   * Changes the speed of sample playback, i.e. a cheap way of changing pitch.
   *
   * @name speed
   * @param {number | Pattern} speed -inf to inf, negative numbers play the sample backwards.
   * @example
   * s("bd").speed("<1 2 4 1 -2 -4>").osc()
   * @example
   * speed("1 1.5*2 [2 1.1]").s("sax").cut(1).osc()
   *
   */
docs.description: Changes the speed of sample playback, i.e. a cheap way of changing pitch.
docs.name: speed

params.description: inf to inf, negative numbers play the sample backwards.
params.name: speed

docs.comment:
/**
   * Used in conjunction with {@link speed}, accepts values of "r" (rate, default behavior), "c" (cycles), or "s" (seconds). Using `unit "c"` means `speed` will be interpreted in units of cycles, e.g. `speed "1"` means samples will be stretched to fill a cycle. Using `unit "s"` means the playback speed will be adjusted so that the duration is the number of seconds specified by `speed`.
   *
   * @name unit
   * @param {number | string | Pattern} unit see description above
   * @example
   * speed("1 2 .5 3").s("bd").unit("c").osc()
   *
   */
docs.description: Used in conjunction with {@link speed}, accepts values of "r" (rate, default behavior), "c" (cycles), or "s" (seconds). Using unit "c" means speed will be interpreted in units of cycles, e.g. speed "1" means samples will be stretched to fill a cycle. Using unit "s" means the playback speed will be adjusted so that the duration is the number of seconds specified by speed.
docs.name: unit

docs.comment:
/**
   * Made by Calum Gunn. Reminiscent of some weird mixture of filter, ring-modulator and pitch-shifter. The SuperCollider manual defines Squiz as:
   *
   * "A simplistic pitch-raising algorithm. It's not meant to sound natural; its sound is reminiscent of some weird mixture of filter, ring-modulator and pitch-shifter, depending on the input. The algorithm works by cutting the signal into fragments (delimited by upwards-going zero-crossings) and squeezing those fragments in the time domain (i.e. simply playing them back faster than they came in), leaving silences inbetween. All the parameters apart from memlen can be modulated."
   *
   * @name squiz
   * @param {number | Pattern} squiz Try passing multiples of 2 to it - 2, 4, 8 etc.
   * @example
   * squiz("2 4/2 6 [8 16]").s("bd").osc()
   *
   */
docs.description:
Made by Calum Gunn. Reminiscent of some weird mixture of filter, ring-modulator and pitch-shifter. The SuperCollider manual defines Squiz as:

"A simplistic pitch-raising algorithm. It's not meant to sound natural; its sound is reminiscent of some weird mixture of filter, ring-modulator and pitch-shifter, depending on the input. The algorithm works by cutting the signal into fragments (delimited by upwards-going zero-crossings) and squeezing those fragments in the time domain (i.e. simply playing them back faster than they came in), leaving silences inbetween. All the parameters apart from memlen can be modulated."
docs.name: squiz

params.description: Try passing multiples of 2 to it - 2, 4, 8 etc.
params.name: squiz

docs.comment:
/**
   *
   * Formant filter to make things sound like vowels.
   *
   * @name vowel
   * @param {string | Pattern} vowel You can use a e i o u. Use a rest (~) to override the effect
   * @example
   * vowel("a e i [o u]").slow(2)
   * .n("<[0,7]!4 [2,7]!4>")
   * .s('supersquare').osc()
   *
   */
docs.description: Formant filter to make things sound like vowels.
docs.name: vowel

params.description: You can use a e i o u. Use a rest (~) to override the effect
params.name: vowel

docs.comment:
/**
 * Intended for a debugging, drawLine renders the pattern as a string, where each character represents the same time span.
 * Should only be used with single characters as values, otherwise the character slots will be messed up.
 * Character legend:
 *
 * - "|" cycle separator
 * - "-" hold previous value
 * - "." silence
 *
 * @param {Pattern} pattern the pattern to use
 * @param {number} chars max number of characters (approximately)
 * @returns string
 * @example
 * const line = drawLine("0 [1 2 3]", 10); // |0--123|0--123
 * console.log(line);
 */
docs.description:
Intended for a debugging, drawLine renders the pattern as a string, where each character represents the same time span. Should only be used with single characters as values, otherwise the character slots will be messed up. Character legend:

  • "|" cycle separator
  • "-" hold previous value
  • "." silence
docs.name: drawLine

docs.comment:
/**
 * Changes the structure of the pattern to form an euclidean rhythm.
 * Euclidian rhythms are rhythms obtained using the greatest common divisor of two numbers.
 * They were described in 2004 by Godfried Toussaint, a canadian computer scientist.
 * Euclidian rhythms are really useful for computer/algorithmic music because they can accurately
 * describe a large number of rhythms used in the most important music world traditions.
 *
 * @memberof Pattern
 * @param {number} pulses the number of onsets / beats
 * @param {number} steps the number of steps to fill
 * @param {number} rotation (optional) offset in steps
 * @returns Pattern
 * @example // The Cuban tresillo pattern.
 * "c3".euclid(3,8)
 * @example // A thirteenth century Persian rhythm called Khafif-e-ramal.
 * "c3".euclid(2,5)
 * @example // The archetypal pattern of the Cumbia from Colombia, as well as a Calypso rhythm from Trinidad.
 * "c3".euclid(3,4)
 * @example // Another thirteenth century Persian rhythm by the name of Khafif-e-ramal, as well as a Rumanian folk-dance rhythm.
 * "c3".euclid(3,5,2)
 * @example // A Ruchenitza rhythm used in a Bulgarian folk-dance.
 * "c3".euclid(3,7)
 * @example // The Cuban tresillo pattern.
 * "c3".euclid(3,8)
 * @example // Another Ruchenitza Bulgarian folk-dance rhythm.
 * "c3".euclid(4,7)
 * @example // The Aksak rhythm of Turkey.
 * "c3".euclid(4,9)
 * @example // The metric pattern used by Frank Zappa in his piece titled Outside Now.
 * "c3".euclid(4,11)
 * @example // Yields the York-Samai pattern, a popular Arab rhythm.
 * "c3".euclid(5,6)
 * @example // The Nawakhat pattern, another popular Arab rhythm.
 * "c3".euclid(5,7)
 * @example // The Cuban cinquillo pattern.
 * "c3".euclid(5,8)
 * @example // A popular Arab rhythm called Agsag-Samai.
 * "c3".euclid(5,9)
 * @example // The metric pattern used by Moussorgsky in Pictures at an Exhibition.
 * "c3".euclid(5,11)
 * @example // The Venda clapping pattern of a South African childrens song.
 * "c3".euclid(5,12)
 * @example // The Bossa-Nova rhythm necklace of Brazil.
 * "c3".euclid(5,16)
 * @example // A typical rhythm played on the Bendir (frame drum).
 * "c3".euclid(7,8)
 * @example // A common West African bell pattern.
 * "c3".euclid(7,12)
 * @example // A Samba rhythm necklace from Brazil.
 * "c3".euclid(7,16,14)
 * @example // A rhythm necklace used in the Central African Republic.
 * "c3".euclid(9,16)
 * @example // A rhythm necklace of the Aka Pygmies of Central Africa.
 * "c3".euclid(11,24,14)
 * @example // Another rhythm necklace of the Aka Pygmies of the upper Sangha.
 * "c3".euclid(13,24,5)
 */
docs.description: Changes the structure of the pattern to form an euclidean rhythm. Euclidian rhythms are rhythms obtained using the greatest common divisor of two numbers. They were described in 2004 by Godfried Toussaint, a canadian computer scientist. Euclidian rhythms are really useful for computer/algorithmic music because they can accurately describe a large number of rhythms used in the most important music world traditions.
examples:
// A thirteenth century Persian rhythm called Khafif-e-ramal.
"c3".euclid(2,5)

// The archetypal pattern of the Cumbia from Colombia, as well as a Calypso rhythm from Trinidad.
"c3".euclid(3,4)

// Another thirteenth century Persian rhythm by the name of Khafif-e-ramal, as well as a Rumanian folk-dance rhythm.
"c3".euclid(3,5,2)

// A Ruchenitza rhythm used in a Bulgarian folk-dance.
"c3".euclid(3,7)

// The metric pattern used by Frank Zappa in his piece titled Outside Now.
"c3".euclid(4,11)

// Yields the York-Samai pattern, a popular Arab rhythm.
"c3".euclid(5,6)

// The Nawakhat pattern, another popular Arab rhythm.
"c3".euclid(5,7)

// A popular Arab rhythm called Agsag-Samai.
"c3".euclid(5,9)

// The metric pattern used by Moussorgsky in Pictures at an Exhibition.
"c3".euclid(5,11)

// The Venda clapping pattern of a South African childrens song.
"c3".euclid(5,12)

// The Bossa-Nova rhythm necklace of Brazil.
"c3".euclid(5,16)

// A typical rhythm played on the Bendir (frame drum).
"c3".euclid(7,8)

// A common West African bell pattern.
"c3".euclid(7,12)

// A Samba rhythm necklace from Brazil.
"c3".euclid(7,16,14)

// A rhythm necklace used in the Central African Republic.
"c3".euclid(9,16)

// A rhythm necklace of the Aka Pygmies of Central Africa.
"c3".euclid(11,24,14)

// Another rhythm necklace of the Aka Pygmies of the upper Sangha.
"c3".euclid(13,24,5)
docs.name: euclid

docs.description: Similar to {@link Pattern#euclid}, but each pulse is held until the next pulse, so there will be no gaps.
docs.name: euclidLegato

docs.comment: /** @class Class representing a pattern. */
docs.name: Pattern
docs.description: Create a pattern. As an end user, you will most likely not create a Pattern directly.

params.description: The function that maps a {@link State} to an array of {@link Hap}.
params.name: query

docs.description: query haps insude the tiven time span
examples:
const pattern = sequence('a', ['b', 'c']);
const haps = pattern.queryArc(0, 1);
docs.name: queryArc

docs.comment:
/**
   * Returns a new pattern, with queries split at cycle boundaries. This makes
   * some calculations easier to express, as all haps are then constrained to
   * happen within a cycle.
   * @returns Pattern
   */
docs.description: Returns a new pattern, with queries split at cycle boundaries. This makes some calculations easier to express, as all haps are then constrained to happen within a cycle.
docs.name: _splitQueries

docs.comment:
/**
   * Returns a new pattern, where the given function is applied to the query
   * timespan before passing it to the original pattern.
   * @param {Function} func the function to apply
   * @returns Pattern
   */
docs.description: Returns a new pattern, where the given function is applied to the query timespan before passing it to the original pattern.
docs.name: withQuerySpan

docs.comment:
/**
   * As with {@link Pattern#withQuerySpan}, but the function is applied to both the
   * begin and end time of the query timespan.
   * @param {Function} func the function to apply
   * @returns Pattern
   */
docs.description: As with {@link Pattern#withQuerySpan}, but the function is applied to both the begin and end time of the query timespan.
docs.name: withQueryTime

docs.comment:
/**
   * Similar to {@link Pattern#withQuerySpan}, but the function is applied to the timespans
   * of all haps returned by pattern queries (both `part` timespans, and where
   * present, `whole` timespans).
   * @param {Function} func
   * @returns Pattern
   */
docs.description: Similar to {@link Pattern#withQuerySpan}, but the function is applied to the timespans of all haps returned by pattern queries (both part timespans, and where present, whole timespans).
docs.name: withHapSpan

docs.comment:
/**
   * As with {@link Pattern#withHapSpan}, but the function is applied to both the
   * begin and end time of the hap timespans.
   * @param {Function} func the function to apply
   * @returns Pattern
   */
docs.description: As with {@link Pattern#withHapSpan}, but the function is applied to both the begin and end time of the hap timespans.
docs.name: withHapTime

docs.comment:
/**
   * Returns a new pattern with the given function applied to the list of haps returned by every query.
   * @param {Function} func
   * @returns Pattern
   */
docs.description: Returns a new pattern with the given function applied to the list of haps returned by every query.
docs.name: _withHaps

docs.comment:
/**
   * As with {@link Pattern#_withHaps}, but applies the function to every hap, rather than every list of haps.
   * @param {Function} func
   * @returns Pattern
   */
docs.description: As with {@link Pattern#_withHaps}, but applies the function to every hap, rather than every list of haps.
docs.name: _withHap

docs.comment:
/**
   * Returns a new pattern with the context field set to every hap set to the given value.
   * @param {*} context
   * @returns Pattern
   */
docs.description: Returns a new pattern with the context field set to every hap set to the given value.
docs.name: _setContext

docs.comment:
/**
   * Returns a new pattern with the given function applied to the context field of every hap.
   * @param {Function} func
   * @returns Pattern
   */
docs.description: Returns a new pattern with the given function applied to the context field of every hap.
docs.name: _withContext

docs.comment:
/**
   * Returns a new pattern with the context field of every hap set to an empty object.
   * @returns Pattern
   */
docs.description: Returns a new pattern with the context field of every hap set to an empty object.
docs.name: _stripContext

docs.comment:
/**
   * Returns a new pattern with the given location information added to the
   * context of every hap.
   * @param {Number} start
   * @param {Number} end
   * @returns Pattern
   */
docs.description: Returns a new pattern with the given location information added to the context of every hap.
docs.name: withLocation

docs.comment:
/**
   * Returns a new pattern, with the function applied to the value of
   * each hap. It has the alias {@link Pattern#fmap}.
   * @param {Function} func
   * @returns Pattern
   */
docs.description: Returns a new pattern, with the function applied to the value of each hap. It has the alias {@link Pattern#fmap}.
docs.name: withValue

docs.description: see {@link Pattern#withValue}
docs.name: fmap

docs.comment:
/**
   * Returns a new Pattern, which only returns haps that meet the given test.
   * @param {Function} hap_test - a function which returns false for haps to be removed from the pattern
   * @returns Pattern
   */
docs.description: Returns a new Pattern, which only returns haps that meet the given test.

params.description: a function which returns false for haps to be removed from the pattern
params.name: hap_test

docs.name: _filterHaps

docs.comment:
/**
   * As with {@link Pattern#_filterHaps}, but the function is applied to values
   * inside haps.
   * @param {Function} value_test
   * @returns Pattern
   */
docs.description: As with {@link Pattern#_filterHaps}, but the function is applied to values inside haps.
docs.name: _filterValues

docs.comment:
/**
   * Returns a new pattern, with haps containing undefined values removed from
   * query results.
   * @returns Pattern
   */
docs.description: Returns a new pattern, with haps containing undefined values removed from query results.
docs.name: _removeUndefineds

docs.comment:
/**
   * Returns a new pattern, with all haps without onsets filtered out. A hap
   * with an onset is one with a `whole` timespan that begins at the same time
   * as its `part` timespan.
   * @returns Pattern
   */
docs.description: Returns a new pattern, with all haps without onsets filtered out. A hap with an onset is one with a whole timespan that begins at the same time as its part timespan.
docs.name: onsetsOnly

docs.comment:
/**
   * Returns a new pattern, with 'continuous' haps (those without 'whole'
   * timespans) removed from query results.
   * @returns Pattern
   */
docs.description: Returns a new pattern, with 'continuous' haps (those without 'whole' timespans) removed from query results.
docs.name: discreteOnly

docs.comment:
/**
   * When this method is called on a pattern of functions, it matches its haps
   * with those in the given pattern of values.  A new pattern is returned, with
   * each matching value applied to the corresponding function.
   *
   * In this `appBoth` variant, where timespans of the function and value haps
   * are not the same but do intersect, the resulting hap has a timespan of the
   * intersection. This applies to both the part and the whole timespan.
   * @param {Pattern} pat_val
   * @returns Pattern
   */
docs.description:
When this method is called on a pattern of functions, it matches its haps with those in the given pattern of values. A new pattern is returned, with each matching value applied to the corresponding function.

In this appBoth variant, where timespans of the function and value haps are not the same but do intersect, the resulting hap has a timespan of the intersection. This applies to both the part and the whole timespan.
docs.name: appBoth

docs.comment:
/**
   * As with {@link Pattern#appBoth}, but the `whole` timespan is not the intersection,
   * but the timespan from the function of patterns that this method is called
   * on. In practice, this means that the pattern structure, including onsets,
   * are preserved from the pattern of functions (often referred to as the left
   * hand or inner pattern).
   * @param {Pattern} pat_val
   * @returns Pattern
   */
docs.description: As with {@link Pattern#appBoth}, but the whole timespan is not the intersection, but the timespan from the function of patterns that this method is called on. In practice, this means that the pattern structure, including onsets, are preserved from the pattern of functions (often referred to as the left hand or inner pattern).
docs.name: appLeft

docs.comment:
/**
   * As with {@link Pattern#appLeft}, but `whole` timespans are instead taken from the
   * pattern of values, i.e. structure is preserved from the right hand/outer
   * pattern.
   * @param {Pattern} pat_val
   * @returns Pattern
   */
docs.description: As with {@link Pattern#appLeft}, but whole timespans are instead taken from the pattern of values, i.e. structure is preserved from the right hand/outer pattern.
docs.name: appRight

docs.comment:
/**
   * Queries the pattern for the first cycle, returning Haps. Mainly of use when
   * debugging a pattern.
   * @param {Boolean} with_context - set to true, otherwise the context field
   * will be stripped from the resulting haps.
   * @returns [Hap]
   */
docs.description: Queries the pattern for the first cycle, returning Haps. Mainly of use when debugging a pattern.

params.description: set to true, otherwise the context field will be stripped from the resulting haps.
params.name: with_context

docs.name: firstCycle

docs.description: Accessor for a list of values returned by querying the first cycle.

docs.description: More human-readable version of the {@link Pattern#_firstCycleValues} accessor.
docs.name: _showFirstCycle

docs.comment:
/**
   * Returns a new pattern, which returns haps sorted in temporal order. Mainly
   * of use when comparing two patterns for equality, in tests.
   * @returns Pattern
   */
docs.description: Returns a new pattern, which returns haps sorted in temporal order. Mainly of use when comparing two patterns for equality, in tests.
docs.name: _sortHapsByPart

docs.comment:
/**
   * Assumes a numerical pattern. Returns a new pattern with all values rounded
   * to the nearest integer.
   * @returns Pattern
   */
docs.description: Assumes a numerical pattern. Returns a new pattern with all values rounded to the nearest integer.
docs.name: round

docs.comment:
/**
   * Assumes a numerical pattern. Returns a new pattern with all values set to
   * their mathematical floor. E.g. `3.7` replaced with to `3`, and `-4.2`
   * replaced with `-5`.
   * @returns Pattern
   */
docs.description: Assumes a numerical pattern. Returns a new pattern with all values set to their mathematical floor. E.g. 3.7 replaced with to 3, and -4.2 replaced with -5.
docs.name: floor

docs.comment:
/**
   * Assumes a numerical pattern. Returns a new pattern with all values set to
   * their mathematical ceiling. E.g. `3.2` replaced with `4`, and `-4.2`
   * replaced with `-4`.
   * @returns Pattern
   */
docs.description: Assumes a numerical pattern. Returns a new pattern with all values set to their mathematical ceiling. E.g. 3.2 replaced with 4, and -4.2 replaced with -4.
docs.name: ceil

docs.comment:
/**
   * Assumes a numerical pattern, containing unipolar values in the range 0 ..
   * 1. Returns a new pattern with values scaled to the bipolar range -1 .. 1
   * @returns Pattern
   */
docs.description:
Assumes a numerical pattern, containing unipolar values in the range 0 ..

  1. Returns a new pattern with values scaled to the bipolar range -1 .. 1
docs.name: _toBipolar

docs.comment:
/**
   * Assumes a numerical pattern, containing bipolar values in the range -1 ..
   * 1. Returns a new pattern with values scaled to the unipolar range 0 .. 1
   * @returns Pattern
   */
docs.description:
Assumes a numerical pattern, containing bipolar values in the range -1 ..

  1. Returns a new pattern with values scaled to the unipolar range 0 .. 1
docs.name: _fromBipolar

docs.comment:
/**
   * Assumes a numerical pattern, containing unipolar values in the range 0 ..
   * 1. Returns a new pattern with values scaled to the given min/max range.
   * @param {Number} min
   * @param {Number} max
   * @returns Pattern
   */
docs.description:
Assumes a numerical pattern, containing unipolar values in the range 0 ..

  1. Returns a new pattern with values scaled to the given min/max range.
docs.name: range

docs.comment:
/**
   * Assumes a numerical pattern, containing unipolar values in the range 0 ..
   * 1. Returns a new pattern with values scaled to the given min/max range,
   * following an exponential curve.
   * @param {Number} min
   * @param {Number} max
   * @returns Pattern
   */
docs.description:
Assumes a numerical pattern, containing unipolar values in the range 0 ..

  1. Returns a new pattern with values scaled to the given min/max range, following an exponential curve.
docs.name: rangex

docs.comment:
/**
   * Assumes a numerical pattern, containing bipolar values in the range -1 ..
   * 1. Returns a new pattern with values scaled to the given min/max range.
   * @param {Number} min
   * @param {Number} max
   * @returns Pattern
   */
docs.description:
Assumes a numerical pattern, containing bipolar values in the range -1 ..

  1. Returns a new pattern with values scaled to the given min/max range.
docs.name: range2

docs.comment:
/**
   * Speed up a pattern by the given factor.
   *
   * @name fast
   * @memberof Pattern
   * @param {number | Pattern} factor speed up factor
   * @returns Pattern
   * @example
   * seq(e5, b4, d5, c5).fast(2)
   */
docs.description: Speed up a pattern by the given factor.
docs.name: fast

docs.comment:
/**
   * Slow down a pattern over the given number of cycles.
   *
   * @name slow
   * @memberof Pattern
   * @param {number | Pattern} factor slow down factor
   * @returns Pattern
   * @example
   * seq(e5, b4, d5, c5).slow(2)
   */
docs.description: Slow down a pattern over the given number of cycles.
docs.name: slow

docs.comment:
/**
   * Returns a new pattern where every other cycle is played once, twice as
   * fast, and offset in time by one quarter of a cycle. Creates a kind of
   * breakbeat feel.
   * @returns Pattern
   */
docs.description: Returns a new pattern where every other cycle is played once, twice as fast, and offset in time by one quarter of a cycle. Creates a kind of breakbeat feel.
docs.name: brak

docs.comment:
/** A discrete value that repeats once per cycle:
 *
 * @param {any} value - The value to repeat
 * @returns {Pattern}
 * @example
 * pure('e4')
 */
docs.description: A discrete value that repeats once per cycle:
docs.name: pure

docs.comment:
/** The given items are played at the same time at the same length:
 *
 * @param {...any} items - The items to stack
 * @return {Pattern}
 * @example
 * stack(g3, b3, [e4, d4])
 */
docs.description: The given items are played at the same time at the same length:
docs.name: stack

docs.description:
Concatenation: combines a list of patterns, switching between them successively, one per cycle:

synonyms: {@link cat}
docs.name: slowcat

docs.description: Concatenation: combines a list of patterns, switching between them successively, one per cycle. Unlike slowcat, this version will skip cycles.
docs.name: slowcatPrime

docs.comment:
/** Concatenation: as with {@link slowcat}, but squashes a cycle from each pattern into one cycle
 *
 * Synonyms: {@link seq}, {@link sequence}
 *
 * @param {...any} items - The items to concatenate
 * @return {Pattern}
 * @example
 * fastcat(e5, b4, [d5, c5])
 * // sequence(e5, b4, [d5, c5])
 * // seq(e5, b4, [d5, c5])
 */
docs.description:
Concatenation: as with {@link slowcat}, but squashes a cycle from each pattern into one cycle

Synonyms: {@link seq}, {@link sequence}
docs.name: fastcat

docs.comment: /** See {@link slowcat} */
docs.description: See {@link slowcat}
docs.name: cat

docs.description: Like {@link fastcat}, but where each step has a temporal weight:
docs.name: timeCat

docs.comment: /** See {@link fastcat} */
docs.description: See {@link fastcat}
docs.name: sequence

docs.comment: /** See {@link fastcat} */
docs.description: See {@link fastcat}
docs.name: seq

docs.comment:
/**
 *
 * Sends each hap as an OSC message, which can be picked up by SuperCollider or any other OSC-enabled software.
 *
 * @name osc
 * @memberof Pattern
 * @returns Pattern
 */
docs.description: Sends each hap as an OSC message, which can be picked up by SuperCollider or any other OSC-enabled software.
docs.name: osc

docs.comment:
/**
 * Change the pitch of each value by the given amount. Expects numbers or note strings as values.
 * The amount can be given as a number of semitones or as a string in interval short notation.
 * If you don't care about enharmonic correctness, just use numbers. Otherwise, pass the interval of
 * the form: ST where S is the degree number and T the type of interval with
 *
 * - M = major
 * - m = minor
 * - P = perfect
 * - A = augmented
 * - d = diminished
 *
 * Examples intervals:
 *
 * - 1P = unison
 * - 3M = major third
 * - 3m = minor third
 * - 4P = perfect fourth
 * - 4A = augmented fourth
 * - 5P = perfect fifth
 * - 5d = diminished fifth
 *
 * @param {string | number} amount Either number of semitones or interval string.
 * @returns Pattern
 * @memberof Pattern
 * @name transpose
 * @example
 * "c2 c3".fast(2).transpose("<0 -2 5 3>".slow(2)).transpose(0)
 * @example
 * "c2 c3".fast(2).transpose("<1P -2M 4P 3m>".slow(2)).transpose(0)
 */
docs.description:
Change the pitch of each value by the given amount. Expects numbers or note strings as values. The amount can be given as a number of semitones or as a string in interval short notation. If you don't care about enharmonic correctness, just use numbers. Otherwise, pass the interval of the form: ST where S is the degree number and T the type of interval with

  • M = major
  • m = minor
  • P = perfect
  • A = augmented
  • d = diminished

Examples intervals:

  • 1P = unison
  • 3M = major third
  • 3m = minor third
  • 4P = perfect fourth
  • 4A = augmented fourth
  • 5P = perfect fifth
  • 5d = diminished fifth

params.description: Either number of semitones or interval string.
params.name: amount

docs.name: transpose

docs.comment:
/**
 * Transposes notes inside the scale by the number of steps.
 * Expected to be called on a Pattern which already has a {@link Pattern#scale}
 *
 * @memberof Pattern
 * @name scaleTranspose
 * @param {offset} offset number of steps inside the scale
 * @returns Pattern
 * @example
 * "-8 [2,4,6]"
 * .scale('C4 bebop major')
 * .scaleTranspose("<0 -1 -2 -3 -4 -5 -6 -4>")
 */
docs.description: Transposes notes inside the scale by the number of steps. Expected to be called on a Pattern which already has a {@link Pattern#scale}
docs.name: scaleTranspose

docs.comment:
/**
 * Turns numbers into notes in the scale (zero indexed). Also sets scale for other scale operations, like {@link Pattern#scaleTranspose}.
 *
 * The scale name has the form "TO? N" wher
 *
 * - T = Tonic
 * - O = Octave (optional, defaults to 3)
 * - N = Name of scale, available names can be found [here](https://github.com/tonaljs/tonal/blob/main/packages/scale-type/data.ts).
 *
 * @memberof Pattern
 * @name scale
 * @param {string} scale Name of scale
 * @returns Pattern
 * @example 
 * "0 2 4 6 4 2"
 * .scale(seq('C2 major', 'C2 minor').slow(2))
 */
docs.description:
Turns numbers into notes in the scale (zero indexed). Also sets scale for other scale operations, like {@link Pattern#scaleTranspose}.

The scale name has the form "TO? N" wher

  • T = Tonic
  • O = Octave (optional, defaults to 3)
  • N = Name of scale, available names can be found here.
docs.name: scale

docs.comment:
/**
 * Turns chord symbols into voicings, using the smoothest voice leading possible.
 * Uses [chord-voicings package](https://github.com/felixroos/chord-voicings#chord-voicings).
 *
 * @name voicings
 * @memberof Pattern
 * @param {range} range note range for possible voicings (optional, defaults to `['F3', 'A4']`)
 * @returns Pattern
 * @example
 * stack("<C^7 A7 Dm7 G7>".voicings(), "<C3 A2 D3 G2>")
 */
docs.description: Turns chord symbols into voicings, using the smoothest voice leading possible. Uses chord-voicings package.
docs.name: voicings

params.description: note range for possible voicings (optional, defaults to ['F3', 'A4'])
params.name: range

examples: stack("<C^7 A7 Dm7 G7>".voicings(), "<C3 A2 D3 G2>")
